segment.source: Optimize your XAML layout
segment.target: Optimize your XAML layout

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Panel
segment.target: Panel

segment.source: Layout is the process of defining the visual structure for your UI.
segment.target: Layout is the process of defining the visual structure for your UI.

segment.source: The primary mechanism for describing layout in XAML is through panels, which are container objects that enable you to position and arrange the UI elements within them.
segment.target: The primary mechanism for describing layout in XAML is through panels, which are container objects that enable you to position and arrange the UI elements within them.

segment.source: Layout can be an expensive part of a XAML app—both in CPU usage and memory overhead.
segment.target: Layout can be an expensive part of a XAML app—both in CPU usage and memory overhead.

segment.source: Here are some simple steps you can take to improve the layout performance of your XAML app.
segment.target: Here are some simple steps you can take to improve the layout performance of your XAML app.

segment.source: Reduce layout structure
segment.target: Reduce layout structure

segment.source: The biggest gain in layout performance comes from simplifying the hierarchical structure of the tree of UI elements.
segment.target: The biggest gain in layout performance comes from simplifying the hierarchical structure of the tree of UI elements.

segment.source: Panels exist in the visual tree, but they are structural elements, not pixel producing elements like a Button or a Rectangle.
segment.target: Panels exist in the visual tree, but they are structural elements, not pixel producing elements like a Button or a Rectangle.

segment.source: Simplifying the tree by reducing the number of non-pixel-producing elements typically provides a significant performance increase.
segment.target: Simplifying the tree by reducing the number of non-pixel-producing elements typically provides a significant performance increase.

segment.source: Many UIs are implemented by nesting panels which results in deep, complex trees of panels and elements.
segment.target: Many UIs are implemented by nesting panels which results in deep, complex trees of panels and elements.

segment.source: It is convenient to nest panels, but in many cases the same UI can be achieved with a more complex single panel.
segment.target: It is convenient to nest panels, but in many cases the same UI can be achieved with a more complex single panel.

segment.source: Using a single panel provides better performance.
segment.target: Using a single panel provides better performance.

segment.source: When to reduce layout structure
segment.target: When to reduce layout structure

segment.source: Reducing layout structure in a trivial way—for example, reducing one nested panel from your top-level page—does not have a noticeable effect.
segment.target: Reducing layout structure in a trivial way—for example, reducing one nested panel from your top-level page—does not have a noticeable effect.

segment.source: The largest performance gains come from reducing layout structure that's repeated in the UI, like in a ListView or GridView.
segment.target: The largest performance gains come from reducing layout structure that's repeated in the UI, like in a ListView or GridView.

segment.source: These ItemsControl elements use a DataTemplate, which defines a subtree of UI elements that is instantiated many times.
segment.target: These ItemsControl elements use a DataTemplate, which defines a subtree of UI elements that is instantiated many times.

segment.source: When the same subtree is being duplicated many times in your app, any improvements to the performance of that subtree has a multiplicative effect on the overall performance of your app.
segment.target: When the same subtree is being duplicated many times in your app, any improvements to the performance of that subtree has a multiplicative effect on the overall performance of your app.

segment.source: Examples
segment.target: Examples

segment.source: Consider the following UI.
segment.target: Consider the following UI.

segment.source: Form layout example These examples shows 3 ways of implementing the same UI.
segment.target: Form layout example These examples shows 3 ways of implementing the same UI.

segment.source: Each implementation choice results in nearly identical pixels on the screen, but differs substantially in the implementation details.
segment.target: Each implementation choice results in nearly identical pixels on the screen, but differs substantially in the implementation details.

segment.source: Option1: Nested StackPanel elements
segment.target: Option1: Nested StackPanel elements

segment.source: Although this is the simplest model, it uses 5 panel elements and results in significant overhead.
segment.target: Although this is the simplest model, it uses 5 panel elements and results in significant overhead.

segment.source: Option 2: A single Grid
segment.target: Option 2: A single Grid

segment.source: The Grid adds some complexity, but uses only a single panel element.
segment.target: The Grid adds some complexity, but uses only a single panel element.

segment.source: Option 3: A single RelativePanel:
segment.target: Option 3: A single RelativePanel:

segment.source: This single panel is also a bit more complex than using nested panels, but may be easier to understand and maintain than a Grid.
segment.target: This single panel is also a bit more complex than using nested panels, but may be easier to understand and maintain than a Grid.

segment.source: As these examples show, there are many ways of achieving the same UI.
segment.target: As these examples show, there are many ways of achieving the same UI.

segment.source: You should choose by carefully considering all the tradeoffs, including performance, readability, and maintainability.
segment.target: You should choose by carefully considering all the tradeoffs, including performance, readability, and maintainability.

segment.source: Use single-cell grids for overlapping UI
segment.target: Use single-cell grids for overlapping UI

segment.source: A common UI requirement is to have a layout where elements overlap each other.
segment.target: A common UI requirement is to have a layout where elements overlap each other.

segment.source: Typically padding, margins, alignments, and transforms are used to position the elements this way.
segment.target: Typically padding, margins, alignments, and transforms are used to position the elements this way.

segment.source: The XAML Grid control is optimized to improve layout performance for elements that overlap.
segment.target: The XAML Grid control is optimized to improve layout performance for elements that overlap.

segment.source: Important To see the improvement, use a single-cell Grid.
segment.target: Important To see the improvement, use a single-cell Grid.

segment.source: Do not define RowDefinitions or ColumnDefinitions.
segment.target: Do not define RowDefinitions or ColumnDefinitions.

segment.source: Examples
segment.target: Examples

segment.source: Text overlaid on a circle
segment.target: Text overlaid on a circle

segment.source: Two text blocks in a grid
segment.target: Two text blocks in a grid

segment.source: Use a panel's built-in border properties
segment.target: Use a panel's built-in border properties

segment.source: Grid, StackPanel, RelativePanel, and ContentPresenter controls have built-in border properties that let you draw a border around them without adding an additional Border element to your XAML.
segment.target: Grid, StackPanel, RelativePanel, and ContentPresenter controls have built-in border properties that let you draw a border around them without adding an additional Border element to your XAML.

segment.source: The new properties that support the built-in border are: BorderBrush, BorderThickness, CornerRadius, and Padding.
segment.target: The new properties that support the built-in border are: BorderBrush, BorderThickness, CornerRadius, and Padding.

segment.source: Each of these is a DependencyProperty, so you can use them with bindings and animations.
segment.target: Each of these is a DependencyProperty, so you can use them with bindings and animations.

segment.source: They’re designed to be a full replacement for a separate Border element.
segment.target: They’re designed to be a full replacement for a separate Border element.

segment.source: If your UI has Border elements around these panels, use the built-in border instead, which saves an extra element in the layout structure of your app.
segment.target: If your UI has Border elements around these panels, use the built-in border instead, which saves an extra element in the layout structure of your app.

segment.source: As mentioned previously, this can be a significant savings, especially in the case of repeated UI.
segment.target: As mentioned previously, this can be a significant savings, especially in the case of repeated UI.

segment.source: Examples
segment.target: Examples

segment.source: Use SizeChanged events to respond to layout changes
segment.target: Use SizeChanged events to respond to layout changes

segment.source: The FrameworkElement class exposes two similar events for responding to layout changes: LayoutUpdated and SizeChanged.
segment.target: The FrameworkElement class exposes two similar events for responding to layout changes: LayoutUpdated and SizeChanged.

segment.source: You might be using one of these events to receive notification when an element is resized during layout.
segment.target: You might be using one of these events to receive notification when an element is resized during layout.

segment.source: The semantics of the two events are different, and there are important performance considerations in choosing between them.
segment.target: The semantics of the two events are different, and there are important performance considerations in choosing between them.

segment.source: For good performance, SizeChanged is almost always the right choice.
segment.target: For good performance, SizeChanged is almost always the right choice.

segment.source: SizeChanged has intuitive semantics.
segment.target: SizeChanged has intuitive semantics.

segment.source: It is raised during layout when the size of the FrameworkElement has been updated.
segment.target: It is raised during layout when the size of the FrameworkElement has been updated.

segment.source: LayoutUpdated is also raised during layout, but it has global semantics—it is raised on every element whenever any element is updated.
segment.target: LayoutUpdated is also raised during layout, but it has global semantics—it is raised on every element whenever any element is updated.

segment.source: It is typical to only do local processing in the event handler, in which case the code is run more often than needed.
segment.target: It is typical to only do local processing in the event handler, in which case the code is run more often than needed.

segment.source: Use LayoutUpdated only if you need to know when an element is repositioned without changing size (which is uncommon).
segment.target: Use LayoutUpdated only if you need to know when an element is repositioned without changing size (which is uncommon).

segment.source: Choosing between panels
segment.target: Choosing between panels

segment.source: Performance is typically not a consideration when choosing between individual panels.
segment.target: Performance is typically not a consideration when choosing between individual panels.

segment.source: That choice is typically made by considering which panel provides the layout behavior that is closest to the UI you’re implementing.
segment.target: That choice is typically made by considering which panel provides the layout behavior that is closest to the UI you’re implementing.

segment.source: For example, if you’re choosing between Grid, StackPanel , and RelativePanel, you should choose the panel that provides the closest mapping to your mental model of the implementation.
segment.target: For example, if you’re choosing between Grid, StackPanel , and RelativePanel, you should choose the panel that provides the closest mapping to your mental model of the implementation.

segment.source: Every XAML panel is optimized for good performance, and all the panels provide similar performance for similar UI.
segment.target: Every XAML panel is optimized for good performance, and all the panels provide similar performance for similar UI.
